children.name: To hope that st will happen or that st is true
hope
children.definition: /həʊp/
examples: ▪ See you soon, I hope!
▪ Even when everyone else thought he was dead, Julie never stopped hoping.
hope (that)
▪ We hurried out of the building, hoping that no one would see us leave.
hope to do something
▪ Bob’s hoping to travel to Africa next year.
hope for
▪ I’m hoping for a better salary in my next job.
I hope sospoken
▪ ‘Have we got enough money for the rent?’ ‘I don’t know. I hope so.’
hope and pray
▪ She could only hope and pray that Liza would be back to her normal self the next time she saw her.
hope[countable noun]
▪ Everett soon forgot all his hopes of fame and fortune.
▪ My hope is that Peter will realize his mistake and apologize.

children.name: in the hope that
children.definition: British /in hopes that American /ɪn ðə ˈhəʊp ðət, ɪn ˈhəʊps ðət/ if you do something in the hope that it will have agoodresult, you do it because you hope it will make something good happen:

children.name: với hy vọng rằng
examples: ▪ He showed me a photo of his wife, in the hope that I might have seen her.
▪ He was rejecting Nancy in hopes that something better might develop with Lydia.

children.name: hopeful
children.definition: /ˈhəʊpfəl/  hoping that something good is likely to happen:
examples: hy vọng
▪ We don’t know if Gascoigne will be fit to play in Saturday’s game, but we’re all hopeful.
hopeful (that)
▪ I’m quite hopeful that I’ll get the job.
hopeful about
▪ James felt more hopeful about his future after his chat with his professor.
be hopeful of (doing) something
British
▪ The local police are hopeful of catching those responsible for the graffiti.
hopefully[adverb]
▪ ‘Will there be any food left over?’ he asked hopefully.

children.name: keep your fingers crossed
children.definition: /ˌkiːp jɔːʳ ˈfɪŋgəʳz ˌkrɒstǁ-ˌkrɔːst/  use this to say that you hope that something will happen the way you want, when you cannot do anything to affect what happens:

children.name: ▪ ‘Have you had your test results yet?’ ‘No. I’m just keeping my fingers crossed.’
examples: ▪ Let’s keep our fingers crossed and hope that this idea of yours works.

children.name: hope for the best
children.definition: /ˌhəʊp fəʳ ðə ˈbest/  to hope that a situation will end well, when it is possible that something might go wrong:
examples: ▪ He never uses a recipe. He just throws all kinds of food into a pan and hopes for the best.

children.name: ▪ Every expectant mother goes into labour hoping for the best
optimistic
children.definition: /ˌɒptɪˈmɪstɪk◂, ˌɒptəˈmɪstɪk◂ǁˌɑːp-/  hoping and expecting that everything will happen in the best way possible:
examples: ▪ Although his lawyers were optimistic, they couldn’t be sure about the final outcome of the trial.
▪ The Democrats went into this election in an optimistic mood.
optimistically[adverb]
▪ Tom said rather optimistically that we could finish the job in a day or two.

children.name: optimistic about
examples: ▪ I am very optimistic about the future of our company.

children.name: cautiously optimisticoptimistic, but realizing that a good result is not definite
examples: ▪ The patient is still in a critical condition but doctors say they are cautiously optimistic that he will make a full recovery.

children.name: pin your hopes on
children.definition: /ˌpɪn jɔːʳ ˈhəʊps ɒn/  to hope that one particular thing will happen, because your happiness or all your other plans depend on this:
examples: ▪ Sue is pinning all her hopes on getting this job.
▪ ‘I do hope she remembers.’ ‘Don’t pin your hopes on it’, warned David.

children.name: have high hopes
children.definition: /hæv ˌhaɪ ˈhəʊps/  to be very hopeful and excited about something, so that you would be very disappointed if it did not happen:

children.name: have high hopes of doing something
examples: ▪ Sam has high hopes of going to university next year.
▪ Despite our differences, we came here with high hopes of signing a new treaty.

children.name: have high hopes for
examples: ▪ Japanese car manufacturers have high hopes for increased profits in Europe.

children.name: despair
children.definition: /dɪˈspeəʳ/  to stop hoping and becomeextremelyunhappy, because you think there is no possibility of something happening:

children.name: tuyệt vọng , hết hy vọng
examples: ▪ You mustn’t despair. Nothing is impossible.
▪ He glared at her, despairing.

children.name: despair of doing something
examples: ▪ Kate despaired of ever seeing her husband again.

children.name: lose/give up hope
children.definition: lose hope/give up hope/ˌluːz ˈhəʊp, ˌgɪv ʌp ˈhəʊp/

children.name: mất hy vọng
examples: ▪ Some seeds take a long time to germinate, so don’t lose hope if nothing happens in the first year.

children.name: lose hope/give up hope of doing something
examples: ▪ After his accident, Jack had almost given up hope of ever working again.

children.name: lose hope/give up hope that
examples: ▪ We never lost hope that our son would return one day.

children.name: lose heart
children.definition: /ˌluːz ˈhɑːʳt/  to stop hoping that you will achieve something, because you feel you have not been making much progress:
examples: ▪ I think if he fails again he’ll just lose heart and give up.
▪ The tunnel had never been finished. Perhaps the builders lost heart and abandoned it.

children.name: hopes are fading
children.definition: /ˌhəʊps ɑːʳ ˈfeɪdɪŋ/  use this to say that people are beginning to stop hoping that someone is safe, that something will succeed etc:
examples: ▪ Hopes are fading, but the search for survivors of the earthquake continues.

children.name: hopes are fading for
examples: ▪ Hopes are fading for the missing fourteen year old.

children.name: dash somebody’s hopes
children.definition: /ˌdæʃ somebodyˈs ˈhəʊps/  to make someone completely stop hoping that something will happen or is true:
examples: ▪ I didn’t want to dash your hopes unnecessarily.
dash sb’s hopes of doing something
▪ a shattering knee injury which dashed his hopes of playing in the World Cup

children.name: what you say when you hope st will happen
hopefully
children.definition: /ˈhəʊpfəli/ spokensay this when you hope something will happen:

children.name: hy vọng là
examples: ▪ He’s been resting today, so hopefully he’ll be feeling better tomorrow.
▪ Hopefully we can find a way of solving this problem.

children.name: with any luck
children.definition: alsowith a little luck/wɪð ˌeni ˈlʌk, wɪð ə ˌlɪtl ˈlʌk/ spoken say this when you hope something will happen, even though there is a small chance it might not:
examples: ▪ With any luck, we’ll have this finished by the end of the day.
▪ With a little luck, Ruth will forget all about the party.

children.name: let’s hope
children.definition: /lets ˈhəʊp/ spoken say this when you hope that something will happen, especially because it will be very unpleasant if it does not:
examples: ▪ Let’s hope we can find a parking space.
▪ The whole thing has been nothing but heartache and worry. Let’s hope nothing like it ever happens again.

children.name: if all goes well
children.definition: /ɪf ˌɔːl gəʊz ˈwel/ spoken say this when you hope something will be successful, but you know that success depends on everything happening in the right way:
examples: ▪ If all goes well, I’ll be sailing from Vera Cruz in about a week.
▪ The tunnel should be finished by 2010 if all goes well.

children.name: hope
children.definition: /həʊp/  the feeling that you have when you hope something will happen and you think it is likely to happen:
examples: hy vọng
▪ The Queen sent a message of hope and sympathy to the American people.
hope of
▪ We now have no hope of finding any more survivors.
hope for
▪ Most of these youths have no jobs and no hope for the future.
be full of hope
▪ Thousands of emigrants set off for the New World full of hope.
give/offer somebody hope
▪ Recent reports of a ceasefire agreement have given us new hope.
live in hope
keep hoping for something
▪ We haven’t had much success yet. but we live in hope.

children.name: optimism
children.definition: /ˈɒptɪmɪzəm, ˈɒptəmɪzəmǁˈɑːp-/  the feeling that everything will happen in the way you want it to or that good things will happen in the future:

children.name: sự lạc quan
examples: ▪ There is a mood of optimism among Socialist Party supporters tonight.

children.name: ▪ the optimism of the post-war period
to hope for st even when it is unlikely
hope against hope (that)
children.definition: /cling to the hope that/ˌhəʊp əgenst ˈhəʊp (ðət), ˌklɪŋ tə ðə ˈhəʊp ðət/  to continue to hope very much that something is true or will happen, even when you know it is extremely unlikely:
examples: ▪ Daniel waited all day, hoping against hope that Annie would change her mind and come back.
▪ James was still clinging to the hope that Jo might have made a mistake.

children.name: get your hopes up
children.definition: spoken alsobuild up your hopesBritish /ˌget jɔːʳ ˈhəʊps ʌp, ˌbɪlk ʌp jɔːʳ ˈhəʊps/  to get excited because you hope something will happen, usually when you are later disappointed because it does not:
examples: ▪ I would have told you about this earlier, but I didn’t want to get your hopes up.
▪ I may be able to arrange something, but please don’t get your hopes up.

children.name: on the off chance that
children.definition: /ɒn ði ˈɒf ˌtʃɑːns ðətǁ-ˌtʃæns-/ informalif you do something on the off chance that another thing will happen, you do it because you hope the other thing will happen, even though it seems unlikely:
examples: ▪ They got to the man as quickly as they could, on the off chance that he was still alive, but he was not.

children.name: wishful thinking
children.definition: /ˌwɪʃfəl ˈθɪŋkɪŋ/  when something you hope for or want to believe is very unlikely to happen or to be true:
examples: ▪ I think she likes me -- but maybe it’s just wishful thinking on my part!
▪ Hopes that scientists have found a cure for baldness now seem based more on wishful thinking than reality.

children.name: pipe-dream
children.definition: /ˈpaɪp driːm/  something pleasant or exciting that you like to imagine happening, but which is very unlikely to happen:
examples: ▪ I’d always wanted to travel around the world, but it seemed nothing more than a pipe-dream.

children.name: ▪ ‘What do you think the chances are of lasting peace in the Middle East?’ ‘I think it’s all just a pipe-dream.’
pie in the sky
children.definition: /ˌpaɪ ɪn ðə ˈskaɪ/ informalan idea or plan that is pie in the sky is one that someone wishes or hopes will happen, but is unlikely to happen because it is not very practical:
examples: ▪ Any talk of getting a reasonable response from the terrorists is just pie in the sky.

children.name: promising
children.definition: /ˈprɒmɪsɪŋ, ˈprɒməsɪŋǁˈprɑː-/  seeming likely to be good or successful:

children.name: đầy triển vọng
examples: ▪ The future looks promising for British companies abroad.
▪ The weather outlook for the weekend isn’t very promising.
▪ My grandfather gave up a promising career in law to fight for his country.

children.name: hopeful
children.definition: /ˈhəʊpfəl/
examples: ▪ The fact that the two sides have agreed to hold negotiations is an extremely hopeful sign.

children.name: look hopeful
examples: ▪ Things might get better, but it isn’t looking very hopeful right now.

children.name: sound hopeful
examples: ▪ At the interview they told me I was "the right sort of person'. I thought that sounded kind of hopeful.

children.name: encouraging
children.definition: /ɪnˈkʌrɪdʒɪŋ, ɪnˈkʌrədʒɪŋǁ-ˈkɜːr-/  making you feel more confident and hopeful:

children.name: khích lệ động viên
examples: ▪ The doctor had some encouraging news -- I would soon be able to walk again.
▪ There are one or two more encouraging signs in the economy now.
▪ So far the results of our tests have been very encouraging.

children.name: offer hope
children.definition: /ˌɒfəʳ ˈhəʊpǁˌɔːf-/  if something such as a new situation or discovery offers hope, it makes it possible for people to feel more hopeful that a bad situation will improve:

children.name: offer hope to
examples: ▪ The new treatment may offer hope to thousands of cancer patients.

children.name: offer hope of
examples: ▪ A recent UN initiative seems to offer some hope of a lasting peace settlement in the region.

children.name: raise hopes
children.definition: /ˌreɪz ˈhəʊps/  to make people more confident than before that what they are hoping for will happen:

children.name: raise hopes that
examples: ▪ The latest news has raised hopes that another Western hostage might soon be released.

children.name: raise somebody’s hopes
examples: ▪ Speculation in the press about tax cuts has raised everyone’s hopes.

children.name: auspicious
children.definition: /ɔːˈspɪʃəs/  formal making people hopeful that good things will happen:
examples: ▪ The baseball season got off to an auspicious start with two good wins for the Tokyo Giants.
▪ It is my honour to toast the bride and groom on this auspicious occasion.

children.name: light at the end of the tunnel
children.definition: /ˌlaɪt ət ði ˌend əv ðə ˈtʌnl/  something good that gives you hope that a long and difficult period is going to end soon:
examples: ▪ For Jane there is some light at the end of the tunnel, but many anorexia sufferers continue to suffer in silence.

children.name: see the light at the end of the tunnelrealize that there is hope
examples: ▪ After all the problems we’ve had we’re finally beginning to see some light at the end of the tunnel.

children.name: a ray of hope
children.definition: a glimmer of hope//ə ˌglɪmər əv ˈhəʊp, ə ˌreɪ əv ˈhəʊp/  something that gives you a small reason to hope that a bad situation will improve:
examples: ▪ The news gave a glimmer of hope that Michael might be released from prison early.
▪ The one ray of hope seemed to be the possibility that the enemy would call off their attack because of the weather.

children.name: what you say when you hope st does not happen
I hope not
children.definition: /aɪ ˌhəʊp nɒt/ spoken say this when you hope that what has just been mentioned will not happen or is not true:

children.name: ▪ ‘Do you think she’s lost?’ ‘I hope not!’
examples: ▪ ‘I promise I won’t do it again.’ ‘I certainly hope not,’ replied her mother.

children.name: God/heaven forbid!
children.definition: /ˌgɒd, ˌhevən fəʳˈbɪdǁ ˌgɑːd-/ spoken use this to say very strongly that you hope something does not happen or has not happened:
examples: ▪ ‘She said she was going to find out where you live and come and visit you.’ ‘Heaven forbid!’

children.name: when there is no hope of improvement or success
hopeless
children.definition: /ˈhəʊpləs/
examples: ▪ The firemen tried to stop the flames from spreading, but it was hopeless.
▪ Remember, it’s just when things look hopeless that you sometimes get a lucky break.

children.name: desperate
children.definition: /ˈdespərɪt, ˈdespərət/  so bad that, unless you get help immediately, there is no hope:
examples: ▪ The situation is desperate -- there are just not enough beds in the hospital.
▪ Another two weeks without emergency aid and I’d think things could become quite desperate.

children.name: gloomy
children.definition: /ˈgluːmi/  a gloomy situation is one in which there is very little hope of improvement:
examples: ▪ This latest survey presents a gloomy picture of the Russian economy.
▪ Evidence that the world’s population is increasing faster than ever implies a gloomy prospect for humanity: starvation.

children.name: bleak
children.definition: /bliːk/  a bleak situation is one in which there is very little hope of improvement and will probably get worse:
examples: ▪ His prospects of finding another job are bleak.
▪ The future looked bleak for the Democratic party.

children.name: there is no hope
children.definition: /ðeər ɪz ˌnəʊ ˈhəʊp/ say this when a situation is so bad that it is useless to hope that it will improve:
examples: ▪ The doctor has said there’s no hope. She only has a few weeks to live.

children.name: there is no hope of
examples: ▪ The prison was on a small, rocky island. There was no hope of escape.

children.name: there is no hope for
examples: ▪ I’m afraid there’s no hope for us, unless you can give us the help we need.

children.name: a feeling that it is useless to hope
despair
children.definition: /dɪˈspeəʳ/  an extremely unhappy feeling you have when your situation is so bad that you have stopped hoping:
examples: ▪ Separation from someone you love can bring loneliness and despair.
▪ He gazed at the confusion around him and was overwhelmed by a feeling of despair.

children.name: be in despair
examples: ▪ Dan was in despair. Everything seemed to be going wrong.

children.name: hopelessness
children.definition: /ˈhəʊpləsnɪs, ˈhəʊpləsnəs/
examples: ▪ After a few weeks, our confidence that our embassy had heard of our plight gave way to hopelessness.

children.name: hopelessness of
examples: ▪ Suddenly he saw the utter futility and hopelessness of his mission.

children.name: sense of hopelessness
examples: ▪ Who can really imagine the sense of hopelessness felt by people who commit suicide?
